Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Development of RF System Control and Power Distribution for the International Muon Ionization Cooling Experiment (MICE)
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5). The award supports the development of the solenoidal particle-tracking spectrometer needed for the first phase of the Muon Ionization Cooling Experiment (MICE). There is increasing interest in using particle accelerators to form very intense beams of high-energy muons. Discovered in 1937, the muon (a more massive 'cousin' of the electron) is a subatomic particle whose simple and well-understood interactions with matter make it a useful probe for a range of purposes. However, due to its short average lifetime (2.2 microseconds), it has not been possible to accelerate muons. The key step in demonstrating the feasibility of muon accelerators is the Muon Ionization Cooling Experiment (MICE). This award provides for the development of RF hardware and controls which are necessary to the demonstration of ionization cooling of muon beams. In addition, the award facilitates graduate student training, and K-12 teachers and students will be involved through QuarkNET.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Don Summers and Dr. Lucien Cremaldi, Dept.  of Physics and Astronomy, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677

 

The University Mississippi is helping to develop radio-frequency (RF) cavities including control and power instrumentation at the internationalMuon Ionization Cooling Experiment (MICE)  at Rutherford Laboratory in the UK.Cool muons are the key to  an energy frontier muon collider and  for a neutrino factory where muon decays in  a racetrack-shaped ring  produce neutrino beams to investigate neutrino oscillations first observed by U.S. Nobel Laurette Ray Davis in South Dakota.  A muon collider may be the only practical way to produce massive Higgs bosons far beyond the reach of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN.  Muons are cooled when they lose momentum in all directions by passing through matter. Just longitudinal momentum is replaced by the RF cavities. Mississippi has supplied seven tons of RF equipment --- from cavity parts to power transmission lines to power sources ---to MICE using this grant. Mississippi has done ACE3P finite element simulations of MICE RF cavities to find geometries which reduce the emission of electrons from inner cavity surfaces and allow the cavities to run with higher electric fields for more muon accelration per meter. In summary, MICE will test muon cooling.
